stem: A 78-year-old client is admitted for extreme dizziness. She takes Metoprolol 50mg and Digoxin 0.125mg daily. Based on the documentation in the Geriatric Cardiac Polypharmacy & Rhythm Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Symptomatic bradycardia in an elderly patient.
Background: History of AFib and HTN. Stable meds for 2 years.
Assessment: Heart rate is 38 bpm. Client reports, 'Everything looks like there is a green tint on it.'
Recommendation: Immediate evaluation of Digoxin level.

tabs.title: Polypharmacy & Rhythm Log
tabs.content:

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 88/52, HR 38, RR 18, T 98.2Â°F. SpO2 93% on RA.

actionOptions.text: Withhold both the Digoxin and the Metoprolol
Notify the provider and prepare for potential Digibind administration
Encourage the client to drink a large glass of water to drop the Metoprolol level
Place the client in an upright High-Fowler's position

parameterOptions.text: Continuous EKG rhythm and Heart Rate monitoring
Presence of visual disturbances (Yellow/Green halos) and nausea
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Hypokalemia-Aggravated Digoxin Toxicity (c2). While Metoprolol (Beta-blocker) also slows the heart, the green-tinted vision (Xanthopsia) and the high Dig level (2.8) confirm Digoxin is the primary toxic culprit. The low potassium (3.4) makes the heart more sensitive to Digoxin's toxic effects. The nurse should hold both heart-slowing drugs (a1) and prepare for the antidote (a2). Key parameters: Rhythm stability (p1) and monitoring the classic Dig-tox visuals (p2).
clinicalPearls: Digoxin + Beta-Blockers = Synergistic Bradycardia. This is the 'double-kill' combo for heart rate.
Green/Yellow tint (Xanthopsia) is a specific 'Dig-only' toxic cue.
Hypokalemia is the #1 reason patients on a 'stable' digoxin dose suddenly become toxic.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the bradycardia (38) is 'just the beta-blocker'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If they see colors or have 'halos' around lights, it is DIGOXIN. Beta-blockers don't cause visual tinting.

mnemonic.title: Green Glow
mnemonic.expansion: G-Green vision. L-Low heart rate. O-Overdose of Dig. W-Wasted Potassium (Low K+).
